questions.text: A young patient came with complaints of acute abdominal pain on and off and tingling sensation of limbs and at times weakness of limbs. She had a history of eating paint from the wall of a newly built house. Which of the following enzyme defect will be the cause of her condition? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ALA dehydratase

 

The given clinical history is suggestive of lead poisoning and lead is known to inhibit ALA dehydratase enzyme activity (zinc-containing enzyme).

 

Lead is the most common environmental poison in India. Paint is the major source for exposure, especially in children.

 

More than 10 mg/dL in children and more than 25 mg/dL in adults leads to toxic manifestations.

Anemia, abdominal colic and loss of appetite are very common symptoms.

 

Lead inhibits heme synthesis. Basophilic stippling of red cells is seen in the peripheral blood and bone marrow smears. This is due to the agglutination of ribosomes. Globin synthesis is adversely affected. Lead particularly inhibits ALA-dehydratase and ferrochelatase. Lifespan of RBC is shortened. Anemia enhances lead absorption, lead in turn produces more anemia; thus, a vicious cycle is operating. Lead will inhibit absorption of iron and calcium.

 

Treatment - Calcium dodecyl edetate (Calcium disodium versenate), penicillamine and dimercaprol (BAL) are used as antidotes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ALA synthase: This enzyme catalyzes the first step in heme synthesis but is not directly inhibited by lead.

 

Option C. Heme synthase: Also known as ferrochelatase, this enzyme inserts iron into protoporphyrin IX to form heme. Although lead inhibits this enzyme, ALA dehydratase is more significantly affected in lead poisoning, causing the symptoms described.

 

Option D. Coproporphyrinogen oxidase: This enzyme catalyzes a later step in heme synthesis and is not primarily affected in lead poisoning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lead poisoning inhibits ALA dehydratase, causing symptoms such as abdominal pain, tingling, and weakness of limbs. Paint ingestion, particularly in children, is a significant source of lead exposure.

choices.text: Factors II, VII, IX, and X

questions.text: Which of the following zymogens requires gamma-glutamyl carboxylase? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Factors II, VII, IX, and X

 

Clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X are zymogens of serine proteases that contain glutamic acid residues. These residues undergo vitamin-K-dependent carboxylation via gamma-glutamyl carboxylase to form gamma-carboxy glutamic acid residues. This enables them to bind calcium ions (Ca2+), which is necessary for their activation and subsequent blood clot formation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Factors II, VIII, IX, X: Factor VIII is not a zymogen that requires gamma-glutamyl carboxylase. It is involved in the intrinsic pathway of coagulation but does not undergo vitamin-K-dependent carboxylation.

 

Option C. Factors II, VII, IX, XI: Factor XI is not a zymogen that requires gamma-glutamyl carboxylase. It is activated by thrombin and does not undergo vitamin-K-dependent carboxylation.

 

Option D. Factors II, VIII, X, XI: Neither Factor VIII nor Factor XI are zymogens that require gamma-glutamyl carboxylase. They do not undergo vitamin-K-dependent carboxylation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zymogens are the proprotein form of enzymes (proenzymes) that require proteolytic activation to carry out their function.

 

Inactive form of vitamin K acts as a cofactor in the post-synthetic modification of these zymogens and their activation. This inactive form of vitamin K is recycled back from its oxidized form by the enzyme vitamin K epoxide reductase, which can be inhibited by warfarin or liver failure.

questions.text: Which is not a product of heme catabolism? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Aminolaevulinic acid

 

Heme catabolism is the process by which the heme portion of hemoglobin is broken down. This process begins with the degradation of heme into biliverdin, which is subsequently reduced to bilirubin. This bilirubin is further processed into conjugated bilirubin, urobilinogen, and stercobilinogen. In addition to these products, heme catabolism also generates carbon monoxide and ferrous ion (Fe²⁺).

 

Aminolaevulinic acid, on the other hand, is not a product of heme catabolism but is instead an important precursor in the synthesis of heme. It is formed in the first step of heme synthesis, where succinyl-CoA and glycine combine under the action of the enzyme aminolaevulinic acid synthase.

 

Therefore, while ferrous ion, biliverdin, and carbon monoxide are products of heme catabolism, aminolaevulinic acid is involved in heme synthesis and not in its breakdown.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ferrous ion: This is indeed a product of heme catabolism, as iron is released during the breakdown of the heme group.

 

Option C. Biliverdin: Biliverdin is one of the direct products of heme degradation, and it is subsequently reduced to bilirubin.

 

Option D. Carbon monoxide: This is another product of heme catabolism, and notably, heme catabolism is the only process in the human body where carbon monoxide is produced endogenously.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aminolaevulinic acid is a precursor in the synthesis of heme, not a product of its catabolism.

questions.text: Complex 4 inhibitor is? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cyanide

 

Explanation:


Cyanide is a potent inhibitor of Complex IV (cytochrome c oxidase) in the electron transport chain (ETC). Complex IV is crucial for the final step of the electron transport chain, where it facilitates the transfer of electrons to oxygen, the final electron acceptor, to form water. By inhibiting Complex IV, cyanide prevents the reduction of oxygen, halting ATP production and leading to cellular hypoxia and energy failure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Carbon Dioxide: Carbon dioxide is not an inhibitor of any of the electron transport chain complexes. It is a byproduct of cellular respiration and does not interfere with the function of the ETC complexes.

 

Option C. Oligomycin: Oligomycin is an inhibitor of ATP synthase (Complex V) in the electron transport chain. It binds to the F0 subunit of ATP synthase, blocking the proton channel and preventing proton translocation across the inner mitochondrial membrane. This inhibition halts ATP synthesis from ADP and inorganic phosphate.

 

Option D. Antimycin: Antimycin is an inhibitor of Complex III (cytochrome bc1 complex) in the electron transport chain. It binds to the Qi site of cytochrome c reductase, blocking the transfer of electrons from ubiquinol to cytochrome c, disrupting the proton gradient and halting ATP synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inhibitor of ETC complexes

 

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 123

questions.text: Which amino acid possesses a positive charge at physiological pH? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Arginine

 

Explanation:

 

Arginine, at physiological pH (around 7.4), maintains a positive charge. This is due to its side chain which contains a guanidino group capable of accepting protons. The guanidino group in arginine is a strong base, resulting in a higher pKa value compared to other amino acids, and thus remains protonated and positively charged at physiological pH. This property is essential for its roles in protein interactions and metabolic functions.

 

Other Options:

 

  • a. Valine: This is a nonpolar amino acid with no charge on its side chain at physiological pH.
  • b. Aspartic acid: This amino acid has a carboxyl group in its side chain that is deprotonated and negatively charged at physiological pH.
  • d. Isoleucine: Similar to valine, isoleucine is a nonpolar amino acid with a neutral side chain at physiological pH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Arginine is distinct among the common amino acids due to its positively charged guanidino group at physiological pH, which plays a crucial role in protein structure and function.

questions.text: Liver produces KB but cannot use KB due to absence of which enzyme:  (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thiophorase

 

The liver lacks the enzyme thiophorase (succinyl-CoA:3-ketoacid CoA transferase) necessary to utilize the ketone bodies it produces. This enzyme is required to convert acetoacetate into acetoacetyl-CoA, which can then be further metabolized into two molecules of acetyl-CoA. Acetyl-CoA is a central molecule in energy metabolism and can enter the citric acid cycle (also known as the Kreb’s cycle) to produce ATP.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thiolase: It is the common enzyme of Ketone body synthesis and KB utilization.

 

Option C. HMG CoA synthase: HMG CoA synthase is RLE of ketone bodies synthesis in the liver. It is an enzyme involved in the synthesis of 3-hydroxy-3-methylglutaryl-CoA (HMG-CoA), a precursor molecule in the production of cholesterol and ketone bodies. However, the absence of HMG CoA synthase would impact the overall synthesis of ketone bodies rather than their utilization.

 

Option D. HMG CoA reductase: HMG CoA reductase is an enzyme involved in the synthesis of mevalonate, which is a precursor molecule in the production of cholesterol. However, the absence of HMG CoA reductase in the liver would not directly affect the utilization of ketone bodies. It would primarily impact the synthesis of cholesterol and other downstream products.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The liver plays a crucial role in ketone body metabolism. During periods of prolonged fasting or low carbohydrate intake, the liver produces ketone bodies (acetoacetate and β-hydroxybutyrate) through a process called ketogenesis. These ketone bodies are then released into the bloodstream and can be used as an alternative fuel source by various tissues, including the brain, heart, and skeletal muscles.

questions.text: Which of the following types of collagens is involved in wound healing? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Type III

 

Collagen III is the first to be synthesized in the early stages of wound healing and is replaced by collagen I, the dominant skin collagen. Initially there is random deposition of collagen during the granulation tissue formation which is further enhanced by enzyme-induced covalent cross-linking. This process matures the collagen into complex structures that are reoriented for tensile strength restoration. Collagen remodeling continues for months after wound closure and the tensile strength of the repaired tissue increases to about 80–85% of normal tissue if all processes proceed without any perturbations.

 

Note –

  • Collagen is a major structural protein found in connective tissue.

 

  • Type I is the most abundant form.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type II:

  • Location: Found primarily in cartilage and the vitreous humor of the eye.
  • Function: Provides structural support to cartilage and vitreous body.
  • Disease: Deficiency leads to severe chondrodysplasias and osteoarthritis.

 

Option C. Type IV:

  • Location: Found in basement membranes.
  • Function: Provides structural integrity to the basement membrane.
  • Disease: Deficiency causes Alport syndrome.

 

Option D. Type V:

  • Location: Found as a minor component in tissues containing collagen I.
  • Function: Contributes to the regulation of collagen fibril assembly.
  • Disease: Deficiency causes Ehlers-Danlos syndrome type I (EDS-I).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Properties of Different types of Collagen:

questions.text: A healthcare professional nurse was ordered by a doctor to take patient’s blood sample for glucose estimation. She took this patient’s sample at 8 a.m. which of the following is used to inhibit glycolysis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sodium fluoride


When a blood sample is taken for glucose estimation, it’s important to prevent glycolysis (the breakdown of glucose by red blood cells and leukocytes after collection), because glycolysis would artificially lower the measured glucose level.
 

Sodium fluoride is the most commonly used glycolysis inhibitor in blood collection tubes for glucose testing.
 

Mechanism: It inhibits the enzyme enolase in the glycolysis pathway, effectively halting glucose breakdown.
 

Often combined with potassium oxalate (an anticoagulant) in a gray-top tube for glucose measurement.

 

Other options:


Option A. Sodium citrate – Anticoagulant used mainly for coagulation studies (e.g., PT, aPTT). It works by binding calcium, not by inhibiting glycolysis.
 

Option B. Potassium oxalate – Anticoagulant that binds calcium, but does not stop glycolysis on its own. It’s used in combination with sodium fluoride in gray-top tubes.
 

Option D. EDTA (Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid) – Anticoagulant used for hematology tests (CBC, ESR). It binds calcium but doesn’t prevent glycolysis.
 

Educational Objective:

 

 

When a blood sample is taken for glucose estimation, it’s important to prevent glycolysis (the breakdown of glucose by red blood cells and leukocytes after collection), because glycolysis would artificially lower the measured glucose level.

questions.text: The sequence of vitamin D synthesis is? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Skin- Liver- Kidney

 

The sequence of vitamin D synthesis is skin-liver-kidney.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The synthesis of vitamin D follows the sequence of Skin → Liver → Kidney, with each organ playing a critical role in converting the precursor to its active form.

questions.text: Which of the following amino acid is necessary for conversion of nor-epinephrine to epinephrine? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Methionine

 

Methionine is involved in the conversion of norepinephrine to epinephrine. It donate methyl group in the form of SAM.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tyrosine: It is the precursor amino acid for the synthesis of both norepinephrine and epinephrine in the catecholamine biosynthetic pathway. But it is not directly involved in their intercomversion,

 

Option B. Tryptophan: Tryptophan is not directly involved in the synthesis of norepinephrine or epinephrine. Tryptophan is an essential amino acid and serves as the precursor for serotonin, melatonin, and niacin (vitamin B3).

 

Option C. Phenylalanine: Phenylalanine is not directly involved in the synthesis of norepinephrine or epinephrine. It is an essential amino acid and serves as the precursor for tyrosine through the action of the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methionine is necessary for the conversion of nor-epinephrine to epinephrine.

 

Norepinephrine is methylated by the enzyme N-methyl transferase (NMT) to epinephrine or adrenaline.

 

S-adenosyl methionine (SAM) is the methyl donor. It is mainly produced by adrenal medulla and adrenergic nerve endings. It is stored in chromaffin granules and released into blood.

questions.text: Banding technique used for dicentric chromosomes:(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) C

 

Explanation:

 

Dicentric chromosome is an abnormal chromosome with two centromeres.

 

 

C banding: stains heterochromatin which are regions of the chromosomes at or near centromere. So, C banding will be most useful for dicentric chromosomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. G-banding: G-banding is the most common banding technique and uses Giemsa stain to stain AT-rich regions. It was developed as an alternative to Q-banding due to the cumbersome nature of Q-banding.

 

Option B. NOR-banding: NOR-banding (Nucleolar Organizer Region) is used to stain regions associated with nucleolus formation and is not specifically useful for dicentric chromosomes.

 

Option D. R-banding: R-banding provides a reverse pattern to G-banding, staining GC-rich regions instead of AT-rich regions. It is not specifically useful for identifying dicentric chromosomes.

 

Note –  Q banding: uses quinacrine dye (first used dye) and stains repetitive AT rich regions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

C-banding is the preferred technique for identifying dicentric chromosomes as it specifically stains heterochromatin regions at or near the centromere.

 

Reference: Robbins 10th Ed. / page- 262-263, 293

questions.text: What would be the respiratory quotient if someone is on an exclusive carbohydrate diet? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1

 

The respiratory quotient (RQ) is defined as the ratio of the volume of CO2 produced to the volume of O2 consumed during metabolism. The RQ value varies depending on the type of substrate being metabolized.

 

Respiratory Quotient Values of Carbohydrates:

 

The RQ for carbohydrates is 1. This is because the metabolism of carbohydrates involves the complete oxidation of glucose, which produces CO2 and consumes O2 in a 1:1 ratio. The equation for glucose oxidation is:

 

When an individual is on an exclusive carbohydrate diet, the metabolism of carbohydrates is the primary source of energy, leading to an RQ value of 1. In conditions like diabetes mellitus, where the utilization of carbohydrates is impaired and fat metabolism predominates, the RQ falls below 1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Respiratory quotient (RQ) is defined as the ratio of volume of CO2 produced in L/g to the oxygen consumed in L/g.

questions.text: A young male with a H/o dyslipidemia having ABC-A1 mutation shows the following. See the image and tell the diagnosis. (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tangier’s disease

 

Tangier's disease is an inherited disorder characterized by significantly reduced levels of high-density lipoprotein (HDL) in the blood. This condition can lead to the accumulation of cholesterol in various tissues and organs. Individuals with Tangier's disease may have enlarged orange tonsils and an increased risk of cardiovascular disease as shown in the picture.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wolman's Disease: Wolman's disease is a severe form of lysosomal acid lipase (LAL) deficiency, a rare genetic disorder. It is characterized by the complete absence of the enzyme lysosomal acid lipase, leading to the buildup of fats in various tissues and organs. Symptoms typically appear in infancy and may include hepatomegaly (enlarged liver), splenomegaly (enlarged spleen), diarrhea/steatorrhea (fatty stools), and vomiting. This condition can be life-threatening.

 

Option B. Gaucher's Disease: Gaucher's disease is another genetic disorder caused by the deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase. It results in the accumulation of harmful quantities of glucocerebroside in various organs and tissues, particularly the spleen, liver, and bone marrow. Common symptoms include an enlarged spleen and liver, anemia, low platelet counts, and bone abnormalities. There are different types of Gaucher's disease, and the severity can vary.

 

Option D. Tay-Sachs Disease: Tay-Sachs disease is a genetic disorder that primarily affects the nervous system. It is caused by the absence or deficiency of an enzyme called hexosaminidase A, which leads to the buildup of a fatty substance called GM2 ganglioside in the brain and nerve cells. Symptoms typically appear in early childhood and include developmental regression, loss of motor skills, and a cherry-red spot in the eye. Tay-Sachs disease is progressive and ultimately fatal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tangier’s disease / Hypo alpha lipoproteinemia

 

ABC-A1 transporters are required for efflux of intracellular free cholesterol and phospholipids across the plasma membrane to combine with apolipoproteins, forming nascent high-density lipoprotein-cholesterol (HDL-C) particles (see fig).

 

  • So, in case of defective ABC-A1, HDL cholesterol and PL are not exported, and HDL is not properly formed causing HDL↓ (Hypo alpha-lipoproteinemia).
  • Cholesterol accumulates in reticuloendothelial system causing:
    • Hepatosplenomegaly
    • Enlarged lymph nodes
    • Large orange/ yellow tonsils (due to fat deposition)
  • The characteristic feature of Wolman’s disease is calcification of adrenals. It is also known as cholesterol ester storage disease and occurs due to deficiency of enzyme acid lipase

choices.text: Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase (GALT) deficiency

questions.text: A newborn presents on the 5th day of life with vomiting, severe jaundice, and an inability to tolerate breast milk, although the infant accepts glucose water without issue. Laboratory tests reveal hypoglycemia, a positive Benedict’s test for reducing substances in the urine, and elevated unconjugated bilirubin levels. On examination, the liver is enlarged. What enzyme deficiency is the most likely cause of these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase (GALT) deficiency

 

Explanation:

 

Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase (GALT) deficiency is the cause of classic galactosemia, an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by an inability to metabolize galactose due to a defect in the enzyme responsible for converting galactose-1-phosphate into glucose-1-phosphate. This deficiency leads to the accumulation of toxic substances such as galactose-1-phosphate in the liver, brain, and other organs, resulting in hypoglycemia, jaundice, hepatomegaly, and potential mental retardation if untreated. The positive Benedict’s test, jaundice, and refusal of lactose-containing feeds are hallmark findings of this condition. Early diagnosis and dietary management by eliminating galactose and lactose from the diet are crucial to prevent severe complications.

 

Other Options:

 

A. Fructokinase deficiency: Fructokinase deficiency, also known as essential fructosuria, is a benign condition where fructose is not metabolized efficiently, leading to its excretion in the urine. It does not cause severe systemic symptoms like jaundice or hypoglycemia seen in GALT deficiency.

 

C. Phosphoglucomutase deficiency: This enzyme deficiency affects glycogen metabolism but does not directly involve galactose metabolism and does not present with the typical symptoms of classic galactosemia, such as vomiting, jaundice, or hepatomegaly.

 

D. Sorbitol dehydrogenase deficiency: Sorbitol dehydrogenase deficiency affects the metabolism of sorbitol and fructose, leading to cataracts and osmotic imbalances but does not cause severe systemic symptoms like jaundice or hypoglycemia seen in GALT deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase (GALT) deficiency, or classic galactosemia, is a severe metabolic disorder marked by an inability to properly metabolize galactose, leading to serious systemic symptoms including jaundice, hypoglycemia, and liver dysfunction. Early diagnosis and management through a lactose-free diet are crucial for preventing long-term complications such as mental retardation, emphasizing the importance of newborn screening and prompt intervention in suspected cases of galactosemia.

questions.text: A 35-year-old Farmer on maize diet with diarrhoea, dementia, and dermatitis. Which Vitamin is deficient in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Niacin

 

  • Niacin deficiency, specifically pellagra, is characterized by the "3 Ds": dermatitis (skin changes), diarrhea (digestive symptoms), and dementia (neurological symptoms). The symptoms described in the patient match those of pellagra, making niacin deficiency the likely cause.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thiamine: Thiamine deficiency, also known as beriberi, primarily manifests as neurological and cardiovascular symptoms. It is not associated with dermatitis and diarrhea, which are prominent features of pellagra.

 

Option B. Riboflavin: Riboflavin deficiency, also known as ariboflavinosis, can lead to various symptoms, including sore throat, redness and swelling of the lining of the mouth and throat, and inflammation and redness of the tongue (magenta tongue). While it shares some symptoms with pellagra, such as mucous membrane changes, it does not typically cause dementia and diarrhea.

 

Option D. Pyridoxine: Pyridoxine deficiency, also known as vitamin B6 deficiency, can lead to neurological symptoms but does not typically cause dermatitis or diarrhea. It is not the primary deficiency associated with the symptoms described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The major protein of Maize, “Zein” lacks tryptophan which is required for Niacin biosynthesis. 60 mg of tryptophan gives 1 mg of Niacin in the body. So, pellagra is more common when maize is the staple diet due to decreased synthesis of Niacin. Pellagra is characterized by 3Ds i.e. diarrhoea, dementia and dermatitis. Death and delirium and depression can also occur.

 

Pellagra can also be caused due to Isoniazid therapy as isoniazid inhibits PLP (B6) formation which in turn is required for Niacin synthesis. Vitamin B2 is also required for Niacin synthesis, so, a deficiency either of B2 or B6 or both can cause pellagra.

 

Thiamine (B1) deficiency leads to Beri-Beri. CNS and CVS are affected in dry Beri-Beri and wet Beri-Beri respectively.

 

Main symptoms of Riboflavin deficiency are Cheilosis, Glossitis and Corneal vascularization.

 

Pyridoxine deficiency cause anemia (microcytic, hypochromic) and seizures in infants.

 

Ref-Harper 31st e/pg. 534-535

questions.text: Glycosylated Hb (Hb-A1c) is best detected by: (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ion exchange

 

Ion exchange chromatography is a highly effective method for detecting glycosylated hemoglobin (Hb-A1c). This technique separates hemoglobin molecules based on their net charge differences. Hb-A1c, which is glycated hemoglobin, has a different net charge compared to non-glycated hemoglobin. As a result, it can be quantified accurately using ion exchange chromatography. This method is widely accepted and used in clinical laboratories for monitoring long-term blood sugar control in diabetic patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Affinity chromatography: Affinity chromatography relies on the specific binding between a molecule of interest and a ligand immobilized on a chromatography column. While affinity chromatography can be used for various biomolecular separations, it is not the method of choice for detecting Hb-A1c. The affinity column would need to have a specific ligand that binds selectively to Hb-A1c, and this approach is less commonly employed compared to ion exchange chromatography for this purpose.

 

Option C. Isoelectric focussing: Isoelectric focussing is a technique that separates proteins based on their isoelectric points (pI), which is the pH at which a protein carries no net electrical charge. While this method can separate different hemoglobin variants based on their pI values, it may not be as precise as ion exchange chromatography for quantifying Hb-A1c specifically, as it relies on charge differences related to pI rather than glycation.

 

Option D. Electrophoresis: Electrophoresis is a general technique for separating molecules based on their charge and size differences in an electric field. Hemoglobin electrophoresis can separate different hemoglobin variants, including Hb-A1c, based on their charge differences. However, it may not provide the same level of specificity and accuracy as ion exchange chromatography when it comes to quantifying Hb-A1c.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HPLC based methods are gold standards for measurement of Hb-A1c. These methods further include ion exchange and affinity chromatography-based methods of which Ion exchange method is considered as the best and widely used method followed by affinity chromatography and enzymatic and immunological methods.

 

Ref- https://www.japi.org/v264/hba1c-result-does-it-depend-upon-the-testing-methods-

questions.text: Which of the following shows functional assessment of B1 deficiency? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. RBC Transketolase

 

In thiamine deficiency, erythrocyte transketolase activity is reduced; this is the earliest manifestation seen even before clinical disturbances. Addition of thiamine diphosphate in vitro to erythrocyte lysate resulting in activation of apo transketolase is suggestive of B1 deficiency.

 

Thiamine contains a substituted pyrimidine ring connected to a substituted thiazole ring by means of methylene bridge. The vitamin is then converted to its active co-enzyme form by addition of two phosphate groups, with the help of ATP. It is catalyzed by thiamine pyrophosphotransferase.

 

Physiological Role of Thiamine

 

  1. Pyruvate dehydrogenase: The co-enzyme form is thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP). It is used in oxidative decarboxylation of alpha keto acids, e.g. pyruvate dehydrogenase catalyzes the breakdown of pyruvate, to acetyl CoA, and carbon dioxide
  2. Alpha ketoglutarate dehydrogenase: An analogous biochemical reaction that requires TPP is the oxidative decarboxylation of alpha ketoglutarate to succinyl CoA and CO2
  3. Transketolase: The second group of enzymes that use TPP as co-enzyme are the transketolases, in the hexose monophosphate shunt pathway of glucose
  4. The main role of thiamine (TPP) is in carbohydrate metabolism. So, the requirement of thiamine is increased along with higher intake of carbohydrates.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. RBC Glutathione Reductase:

  • Function: Measures the activity of riboflavin (Vitamin B2).
  • Relevance: Used to assess riboflavin deficiency, not thiamine deficiency.

 

Option C. Serum Thiamine Levels:

  • Function: Direct measurement of thiamine in the blood.
  • Relevance: While it can indicate thiamine levels, it is less specific than functional assays like erythrocyte transketolase activity for assessing functional deficiency.

 

Option D. RBC Glutathione Peroxidase:

  • Function: Measures the activity of selenium and glutathione metabolism.
  • Relevance: Used to assess selenium status, not thiamine deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Thiamine deficiency causes lactic acidosis due to inhibition of: (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) PDH (Pyruvate dehydrogenase)

 

Thiamine deficiency affects the activity of PDH, which is an enzyme complex responsible for converting pyruvate (a product of glycolysis) into acetyl-CoA, a key molecule in the citric acid cycle (Krebs cycle). When PDH is inhibited, pyruvate cannot enter the citric acid cycle, leading to an accumulation of pyruvate, which is then converted to lactic acid, resulting in lactic acidosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pyruvate carboxylase: Pyruvate carboxylase is not directly related to lactic acidosis in the context of thiamine deficiency. Its primary function is to catalyze the conversion of pyruvate to oxaloacetate, which can be used in various metabolic pathways.

 

Option C. Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase (PEPCK): PEPCK is involved in gluconeogenesis, a metabolic pathway that synthesizes glucose from non-carbohydrate sources. It does not directly contribute to lactic acidosis in thiamine deficiency.

 

Option D. Pyruvate kinase: Pyruvate kinase is an enzyme involved in the final step of glycolysis, where it catalyzes the conversion of phosphoenolpyruvate (PEP) to pyruvate. It is not directly associated with lactic acidosis due to thiamine deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pyruvate dehydrogenase is the enzyme affected in a patient with thiamine deficiency who develops lactic acidosis.

 

 

Enzyme performing oxidative decarboxylation need vitamin B1 for their reaction. Some examples are:

  1. PDH
  2. Alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase
  3. Isocitrate dehydrogenase
  4. Branched chain keto acid dehydrogenase

 

Additional Information:

  • Marker for B1 deficiency is Transketolase activity
  • Coenzyme for simple decarboxylation: B6
  • Marker for B2 deficiency is RBC glutathione reductase activity

questions.text: What type of mutation is seen in sickle cell anemia? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Point mutations

 

Sickle cell anemia is caused due to a point mutation in B globin gene wherein adenine is replaced with thymine in the 6th codon of DNA sequence. Thus, the glutamic acid in the 6th position of beta chain of HbA is changed to valine in HbS. This single amino acid substitution leads to polymerization of hemoglobin molecules inside RBCs. This causes a distortion of cell into sickle shape.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Insertion: An insertion mutation involves the addition of one or more nucleotide base pairs into the DNA sequence. This type of mutation is not responsible for sickle cell anemia.

 

Option B. Deletion: A deletion mutation involves the removal of one or more nucleotide base pairs from the DNA sequence. This type of mutation is not responsible for sickle cell anemia.

 

Option D. Frameshift mutation: A frameshift mutation is caused by insertions or deletions of a number of nucleotides that are not divisible by three, resulting in a shift in the reading frame of the codons in the DNA sequence. This type of mutation is not responsible for sickle cell anemia.

 

Educational Objective

choices.text: Mixed meal having all 3 in equal amount

questions.text: The maximum thermic effect is seen with a meal which has? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Protein

 

Increased heat production or increased metabolic rate following the intake of food is called as thermogenic effect of food or diet-induced thermogenesis or specific dynamic action (SDA) of food.

 

Part of this is due to the expenditure of energy for digestion; absorption and active transport of products of the digestion. Another reason for this expenditure of energy is that reserve materials, such as glycogen, triacyl glycerol, protein, etc. are synthesized from small molecules available after digestion.

 

A high protein diet leads to higher protein turnover resulting in increased diet induced thermogenesis.

 

The values of SDA are: for proteins 30%, for lipids 15%, and for carbohydrates 5%. This means that out of every 100 grams of proteins consumed, the energy available for doing useful work is 30% less than the calculated value.

It is a common experience that during hot weather following the consumption of a protein rich meal, one feels hot and humid for a while. On the other hand, in cold weather, the same would provide a comfortable feeling

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fat: Fats have a moderate thermic effect, lower than proteins.

 

Option C. Carbohydrates: Carbohydrates have the lowest thermic effect.

 

Option D. Mixed meal having all 3 in equal amount: A mixed meal would have a combined thermic effect that is a weighted average of the individual macronutrient effects, which would be lower than that of a protein-only meal.

 

Real-world Observation: It is commonly observed that after consuming a protein-rich meal, especially during hot weather, individuals may feel hot and humid due to the increased heat production. Conversely, in cold weather, the same meal can provide a warming effect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The maximum thermic effect is seen with protein-rich meals, as proteins require more energy for digestion, absorption, and metabolism compared to fats and carbohydrates.

questions.text: Vitamin B12 is found maximum in: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Animal products

 

Vitamin B12 is most abundant in animal-derived foods such as meat, fish, poultry, eggs, and dairy products. These sources are rich in this essential vitamin, making it an important part of the diets of individuals who consume animal products.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Green Leafy Vegetables: Green leafy vegetables, while nutritious and a source of many vitamins and minerals, are generally not a significant source of vitamin B12. In fact, plant-based sources of B12 are limited, and green leafy vegetables are not a reliable source of this vitamin.

 

Option C. Roots and Tubers: Roots and tubers are also not a substantial source of vitamin B12. This vitamin is not typically found in plant-based foods in significant quantities, so relying solely on roots and tubers for B12 would likely result in a deficiency.

 

Option D. Sunlight: Sunlight is not a source of vitamin B12. This vitamin is not synthesized by the body through exposure to sunlight, as is the case with vitamin D.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin B12 is naturally present in foods of animal origin, including fish, meat, poultry, eggs, and dairy products. Hence, vegetarians usually are prone to develop vitamin b12 deficiency. Strict vegetarians (vegans) are at risk of developing B12 deficiency.

choices.text: Chloride secretion is decreased in sweat and increased in pancreatic fluid
Chloride secretion is increased in sweat and decreased in pancreatic fluid
Chloride secretion is decreased in both sweat and pancreatic fluid
Chloride secretion is increased in both sweat and pancreatic fluid

questions.text: True regarding CF (Cystic Fibrosis): (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans B) Chloride secretion is increased in sweat and decreased in pancreatic fluid:

 

Explanation:

 

In sweat glands, the defective CFTR leads to decreased chloride reabsorption, resulting in increased chloride secretion in sweat. Therefore, individuals with CF have elevated levels of chloride in their sweat, which is a diagnostic feature of the condition.

 

In the pancreas, the impaired CFTR function leads to decreased chloride secretion into pancreatic fluid. This results in the production of thick, sticky mucus in the pancreatic ducts, leading to pancreatic insufficiency. The pancreas is unable to release digestive enzymes properly into the small intestine, affecting the digestion of food.

 

Educational objective:

 

Cystic Fibrosis (CF) is a genetic disorder caused by mutations in the CFTR (Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductance Regulator) gene. CFTR is a chloride channel that regulates the movement of chloride ions across cell membranes. In individuals with cystic fibrosis, the function of CFTR is impaired.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with recurrent episodes of abdominal pain, pancreatitis, and creamy plasma on laboratory analysis. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of lipoprotein lipase deficiency. Following the consumption of a fatty meal, which substance is most likely to be significantly elevated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Chylomicrons

 

Explanation:

 

In lipoprotein lipase (LPL) deficiency, chylomicrons accumulate in the blood, particularly after consuming a fatty meal. LPL is essential for the hydrolysis of triglycerides present in chylomicrons into free fatty acids, which can be used for energy or stored in tissues. When LPL is deficient or non-functional, chylomicrons are not adequately broken down and thus accumulate in the bloodstream, causing hypertriglyceridemia, abdominal pain, and a higher risk of pancreatitis. This accumulation is especially noticeable after eating foods rich in fats, as chylomicrons are responsible for the transport of dietary triglycerides.

 

Other Options:

 

A. Apolipoprotein B: Apolipoprotein B is a component of VLDL, LDL, and chylomicrons, but its levels do not specifically indicate LPL deficiency. The primary issue in LPL deficiency is the inability to clear triglyceride-rich lipoproteins, rather than a direct effect on apolipoprotein B.

 

C. Lipoprotein (a): Lipoprotein (a) is a genetically determined lipoprotein that is associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular disease. It is not directly involved in triglyceride metabolism or affected by LPL deficiency.

 

D. Sphingomyelin: Sphingomyelin is a type of phospholipid found in cell membranes and lipoproteins, but it is not directly related to triglyceride metabolism or influenced by LPL activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lipoprotein lipase (LPL) deficiency leads to the accumulation of chylomicrons after consuming a fatty meal due to the inability to hydrolyze triglycerides effectively. This enzyme deficiency results in hypertriglyceridemia, which can cause symptoms like abdominal pain and pancreatitis. Understanding the specific lipoproteins affected in lipid metabolism disorders is crucial for accurate diagnosis and management.

questions.text: Cystic fibrosis is caused by which of the following deletion? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Phenylalanine at 508

 

  • Correct. Cystic fibrosis is primarily caused by the deletion of Phenylalanine at position 508 in the CFTR gene. This mutation leads to a malfunctioning CFTR protein, which results in the characteristic symptoms of cystic fibrosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tyrosine at 508: Cystic fibrosis is not caused by the deletion of Tyrosine at position 508. The critical deletion is of Phenylalanine at this position.

 

Option C. Tryptophan at 508: Cystic fibrosis is not caused by the deletion of Tryptophan at position 508. The deletion of Phenylalanine at this position is the key mutation associated with cystic fibrosis.

 

Option D. Lysine at 805: Cystic fibrosis is not caused by the deletion of Lysine at position 805. The F508del mutation is the most common and well-known mutation in cystic fibrosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cystic fibrosis is due to mutation in cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) protein by deletion of one codon which give rise to phenylalanine at position 508 of this protein. Mnemonic: F-fibrosis, F- Phenylalaine

 

This protein helps in movement of H2O and chloride ion in and out of cell and helps in the formation of mucus secretion and saliva.

 

In normal conditions, the channel allows the formation of thin layer of mucus. But in cystic fibrosis, a thick layer of mucus is formed (see fig) causing airway obstruction leading to infection and ultimately scarring of lung tissue.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with complaints of facial puffiness and frothy urine. Given below is the histological image of the condition. What do you think is the diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Membranous nephropathy

 

The image is characteristic of membranous nephropathy. The given hematoxylin and eosin (H&E)-stained image shows uniform, diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall. (Intense pink color)

 

 

Membranous nephropathy is a common cause of the nephrotic syndrome in adults. It is characterized by diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall due to the accumulation of electron-dense, Ig-containing deposits along the subepithelial side of the basement membrane.

 

It is a form of chronic immune-complex-mediated disease.

 

Microscopy:

 

  • Light microscopy: The GBM is thickened without cellular proliferation.
  • Immunofluorescence microscopy: granular deposits containing lg and complement along the glomerular basement membrane
  • Electron micrograph: electron-dense subepithelial deposits (epimembranous spikes) and effacement of foot processes of podocytes

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS): FSGS is characterized by segmental scarring of the glomeruli, which is not seen in the provided image. FSGS also typically presents with focal lesions rather than the diffuse thickening observed in membranous nephropathy.

 

Option C. Membranoproliferative nephritis: This condition is characterized by hypercellularity and a thickened, double-contoured glomerular basement membrane, often referred to as "tram-track" appearance, which is different from the thickened, smooth GBM seen in membranous nephropathy.

 

Option D. Dense deposit disease: Also known as Type II membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis, this condition is marked by ribbon-like electron-dense deposits within the GBM, which is not consistent with the features of membranous nephropathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Membranous nephropathy is characterized by uniform, diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall with subepithelial immune deposits, as evidenced by the histological image provided.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cortans pathologic basis of disease, page no. 1766, 1767

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presented to the hospital with palpitations. Physical examination showed a diastolic murmur in the left 3rd intercostal space. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Aortic regurgitation

 

The presence of a diastolic murmur heard best at the left 3rd intercostal space (Erb's point) is characteristic of aortic regurgitation. Aortic regurgitation occurs when the aortic valve does not close properly, allowing blood to flow back into the left ventricle during diastole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aortic stenosis: This condition produces a systolic ejection murmur, typically heard at the right second intercostal space.

 

Option C. Mitral regurgitation: This condition causes a pansystolic murmur heard best at the apex of the heart and radiates to the axilla.

 

Option D. Tricuspid regurgitation: This condition causes a pansystolic murmur heard best at the lower left sternal border.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aortic Regurgitation is associated with a diastolic murmur, best heard at Erb’s point (left 3rd intercostal space). The murmur is typically described as a high-pitched, blowing, decrescendo murmur.

questions.text: Decreased sexual maturity and hypogonadism seen with deficiency of: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Zinc

 

Zinc is an essential trace element involved in numerous aspects of cellular metabolism. It plays a vital role in immune function, protein synthesis, wound healing, DNA synthesis, and cell division. Zinc is also crucial for normal growth and development during pregnancy, childhood, and adolescence, and it is necessary for the proper functioning of taste and smell.

 

Features of Zinc Deficiency:

 

  • Decreased Sexual Maturity: Zinc deficiency in children and adolescents can lead to growth retardation and delayed sexual maturation, particularly hypogonadism in males.
  • Hypogonadism: This condition is characterized by the underdevelopment of primary or secondary sexual characteristics, such as the testes in males, leading to delayed or absent puberty.
  • Impaired Immune Function: Zinc deficiency can result in an increased susceptibility to infections.
  • Other Symptoms: Include hair loss, diarrhea, delayed wound healing, and eye and skin lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Copper: Deficiency can lead to anemia (microcytic, hypochromic), neutropenia, bone abnormalities, and neurological issues such as peripheral neuropathy and subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord.

 

Option C. Selenium: Deficiency can cause Keshan disease (a type of cardiomyopathy) and Kashin-Beck disease (a type of osteoarthropathy).

 

Option D. Iron: Deficiency is commonly associated with microcytic, hypochromic anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zinc deficiency is associated with decreased sexual maturity and hypogonadism, particularly in male children, and is a common nutritional deficiency in developing countries. It is also linked to impaired growth, immune dysfunction, and delayed wound healing.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child came with complaints of pain over the right lower quadrant and lower back pain. On examination, he had pain over the right side of the hip on passive extension along with a mass in the right lumbar region pointing towards the groin. What is the most likely diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Psoas abscess

 

The given clinical finding of pain on hip extension is “psoas sign” which is seen in inflammation of psoas like abscess or appendicitis. However, presence of mass in right lumbar makes psoas abscess more likely.

 

Psoas abscess is an infection that occurs in the psoas muscle, which is located in the lower back and can extend into the right lower quadrant. It can cause lower back pain, hip pain on passive extension, and the presence of a mass in the lumbar region, making it a likely diagnosis based on the symptoms described.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pyelonephritis: Pyelonephritis is an infection of the kidneys and typically presents with symptoms such as fever, flank pain, and urinary symptoms. While it can cause lower back pain, it doesn't typically result in a palpable mass in the lumbar region.

 

Option C. Appendicitis: Appendicitis usually presents with pain in the right lower quadrant, but it doesn't typically involve lower back pain or the presence of a palpable mass in the lumbar region.

 

Option D. Torsion of right undescended testis: Testicular torsion is a condition involving the twisting of the spermatic cord, which leads to severe testicular pain and swelling. It does not typically cause lower back pain or a palpable mass in the lumbar region.

 

Educational Objective:

 

History of abdominal pain and mass in the right lumbar region, with pain on passive extension of the right hip (psoas sign), points towards the diagnosis of psoas abscess.

 

The history of lower back pain needs to be evaluated with the possibility of tubercular origin to be kept in mind in this patient.

 

Treatment is usually by percutaneous CT-guided drainage and appropriate antibiotic therapy.

questions.text: A woman on anti-depressants presents with bleeding. She gives a history of bulky stools which sticks to the pan. Which of the following vitamin deficiency can cause bleeding in this condition?  (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vitamin K

 

Option D. Vitamin K: Vitamin K is essential for blood clotting, and its deficiency can lead to a bleeding tendency. Bulky stools that stick to the pan can be indicative of malabsorption issues, which could result in inadequate absorption of fat-soluble vitamins, including Vitamin K. This deficiency can lead to bleeding problems.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Vitamin A: Vitamin A deficiency is not typically associated with bleeding disorders but can lead to other health issues, including vision problems.

 

Option B. Vitamin D: Vitamin D deficiency can result in various symptoms, but it is not known to directly cause bleeding disorders.

 

Option C. Vitamin E: Vitamin E deficiency may lead to neurological and muscle problems but is not a common cause of bleeding disorders.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bulky, greasy stools that stick to the pan (often described as "steatorrhea") can be indicative of malabsorption, a condition where the absorption of nutrients, including fat-soluble vitamins, is impaired. Vitamin K is a fat-soluble vitamin crucial for the synthesis of blood clotting factors in the liver. Deficiency of vitamin K can lead to impaired blood clotting and a tendency to bleed.

 

Vitamin K is a fat-soluble vitamin crucial for the synthesis of blood clotting factors in the liver. Deficiency of vitamin K can lead to impaired blood clotting and a tendency to bleed.Top of Form

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 532

questions.text:
Which muscles receive innervation from the Superior Gluteal Nerve? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

1. Gluteus Medius

2. Gluteus Minimus

3. Tensor fascia lata

4. Piriformis
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 1, 2, 3

 

Superior Gluteal Nerve (L4, L5, S1) supplies to Gluteus Medius, Minimus and Tensor Fascia Lata (damage leads to positive Trendelenburg sign). Accompanied by the superior gluteal vessels, the nerve leaves the pelvis via the greater sciatic foramen above piriformis, and divides into superior and inferior branches. The superior branch accompanies the upper branch of the deep division of the superior gluteal artery to supply gluteus medius and occasionally gluteus minimus. The inferior branch runs with the lower ramus of the deep division of the superior gluteal artery across gluteus minimus, supplies the glutei medius and minimus and ends in tensor fasciae latae.

 

Piriformis is supplied by the nerve to the piriformis (S1, S2).

 

 

1. Gluteus Medius: True. The gluteus medius muscle receives innervation from the superior gluteal nerve. This nerve supplies motor neurons to the gluteus medius and plays a crucial role in the abduction and stabilization of the hip joint.
 

2. Gluteus Minimus: True. Similar to the gluteus medius, the gluteus minimus muscle is also innervated by the superior gluteal nerve. It functions in hip abduction and stabilization.
 

3. Tensor Fascia Lata (TFL): True. The tensor fascia lata muscle, often referred to as the TFL, receives innervation from the superior gluteal nerve. This muscle assists in various movements, including flexion, abduction, and medial rotation of the hip.

 

Other Option

 

4. Piriformis: False. The piriformis muscle is not innervated by the superior gluteal nerve. Instead, it is primarily innervated by the nerve to the piriformis, which arises from the sacral plexus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gluteus Medius, Gluteus Minimus, and Tensor Fascia Lata receive innervation from the Superior Gluteal Nerve (L4, L5, and S1 nerve roots). Piriformis, on the other hand, is innervated by one of the branch of sacral plexus.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms is represented by the given form of replication? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Influenza virus

 

The given image shows the replication of influenza virus.

 

Stages of replication:

 

Replication of influenza A viruses in the lung epithelium.

 

Binding of haemagglutinin (HA), expressed on the surface of the influenza virion, with sialic acid residues linked to cell surface glycans induces binding and fusion of the virion with the plasma membrane of the target cell.

 

The virus then enters the cell via endocytosis or micropinocytosis and is trafficked to the lysosome where acidification activates the proton selective matrix protein-2 viral channel (M2), inducing membrane fusion and dissociation of the viral ribonucleoprotein (RNP) core, which is then transported to the nucleus where viral RNA replication occurs.

 

Progeny viral RNP cores are generated in the cytosol and, with the viral surface proteins, HA and neuraminidase (NA), and other viral proteins, are concentrated in and near lipid rafts at the plasma membrane.

 

Budding of these plasma membrane regions forms complete viral progeny, which is linked to the plasma membrane by HA/sialic acid interactions.

 

Cleavage of sialic acid residues by neuraminidase releases the viral progeny so they are then free to infect other cells, which can be prevented by NA inhibitors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hepatitis virus: Hepatitis viruses have different replication mechanisms and do not exhibit the specific stages shown in the image for influenza virus.

 

Option C. HIV: HIV is a retrovirus that integrates its RNA into the host DNA using reverse transcriptase, followed by integration into the host genome, which is not depicted in the given image.

 

Option D. Herpes virus: Herpes viruses have a different replication mechanism involving DNA replication within the nucleus and the formation of nucleocapsids in the nucleus, not shown in the given image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The replication cycle depicted in the image is characteristic of the influenza virus, involving binding of hemagglutinin (HA) to sialic acid residues, endocytosis, acidification within lysosomes, RNA replication in the nucleus, assembly at the plasma membrane, and release mediated by neuraminidase.

questions.text: JAK2 mutation is most commonly associated with? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Polycythemia vera

 

Polycythemia vera is strongly associated with activating point mutations in the tyrosine kinase JAK2.

 

The exact etiology of PV is not known but about a third of cases show inconsistent and varied chromosomal abnormalities such as 20q, trisomy 8 and 9p. Major pathogenetic mechanism is a tyrosine kinase JAK2 mutation which removes the autoinhibitory control and activates the kinases.

 

The JAK2 V617F mutation is an acquired, somatic mutation present in the majority of patients with myeloproliferative cancer (myeloproliferative neoplasms) i.e. nearly 100% of patients with polycythemia vera and in about 50% of patients with essential thrombocytosis and primary myelofibrosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Essential thrombocytosis: The JAK2 V617F mutation is also found in approximately 50% of patients with essential thrombocytosis, but it is most strongly associated with polycythemia vera.

 

Option C. CML (Chronic Myeloid Leukemia): CML is associated with the Philadelphia chromosome (t(9;22) translocation), not the JAK2 mutation.

 

Option D. PMF (Primary Myelofibrosis): The JAK2 mutation is present in about 50% of patients with PMF, but again, it is most strongly associated with polycythemia vera.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The JAK2 V617F mutation is most commonly associated with polycythemia vera, where it drives the excessive production of red blood cells through constitutive activation of the JAK-STAT pathway.

 

Ref: Robbins and cotran pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1161

questions.text: What is the most common ocular manifestation of COVID-19?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Follicular conjunctivitis

 

COVID-19 can cause various ocular manifestations, with follicular conjunctivitis being the most common. This is due to the presence of ACE-2 receptors in the cornea and conjunctiva, making them susceptible to SARS-CoV-2 infection.

 

COVID-19:

 

  • Most common ocular symptoms: Dry eye or foreign body sensation, redness, tearing, itching, eye pain, and discharge.
  • Most common ocular manifestation: Mild follicular conjunctivitis, which can appear as the only sign and symptom of COVID-19.
  • Other less frequent ocular complications: Hemorrhagic conjunctivitis, dry eye disease, episcleritis, chemosis, and photophobia.
  • Intraocular complications that may occur: Retinal artery occlusions, hemorrhages, and cotton wool spots caused by complement-mediated thrombotic angiopathy.
  • Patients with conjunctivitis should undergo a nasopharyngeal RT-PCR test for COVID-19 to rule out systemic infection.
  • Physicians and ophthalmologists should exercise caution when examining patients with conjunctivitis and wear eye-protective gear in addition to face masks and other protective devices.

 

FOLLICULAR CONJUNCTIVITIS:

 

 

  • The follicles appear as gray-white, round to oval elevations which measuring between 0.5 to 1.5 mm in diameter
  • Smaller follicles may produce a slightly irregular and velvety appearance
  • Follicles can be seen in the inferior and superior tarsal conjunctiva, and less often, on bulbar or limbal conjunctiva 
    • Acute follicular conjunctivitis is usually associated with viral (epidemic keratoconjunctivitis, Herpes zoster keratoconjunctivitis, infectious mononucleosis, Epstein-Barr virus infection) or chlamydial infections (Inclusion conjunctivitis), while chronic disease may be caused by chronic chlamydial infection (trachoma, lymphogranuloma venereum) or as a toxic or reactive inflammatory response to topical medications and molluscum contagiosum infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uveitis: There are no consistent reports linking uveitis directly as a common manifestation of COVID-19.

 

Option B. Mucormycosis: Although mucormycosis (commonly known as black fungus) has been seen in COVID-19 patients, it is generally associated with severely immunocompromised states and not directly linked as a typical ocular manifestation of COVID-19 itself.

 

Option D. Papillary Conjunctivitis: This type of conjunctivitis, characterized by cobblestone-like nodules, is more commonly associated with allergic reactions or chronic irritation from contact lenses rather than infectious etiologies like COVID-19.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which component is most abundant in HDL compared to other lipoproteins? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Apoproteins

 

Explanation:

 

High-Density Lipoprotein (HDL) is distinguished from other lipoproteins by its high proportion of apoproteins. This higher protein content contributes to its higher density, which is reflected in its nomenclature. HDL's primary role is to transport cholesterol from the tissues back to the liver, a process known as reverse cholesterol transport. The abundance of apoproteins in HDL is crucial for this function, as these proteins serve as structural components and also play critical roles in lipoprotein metabolism and function.

 

Other Options:

 

  • a. Cholesterol: While HDL carries cholesterol, it is not the lipoprotein with the highest proportion of cholesterol; that distinction belongs to Low-Density Lipoprotein (LDL).
  • c. Triglycerides: HDL contains lower levels of triglycerides compared to Very Low-Density Lipoproteins (VLDL) and chylomicrons, which primarily transport triglycerides from the intestines and liver.
  • d. Fatty acids: Fatty acids are not a primary component of HDL; they are more associated with VLDL and chylomicrons in terms of transport and function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HDL is characterized by a high proportion of apoproteins, which are critical for its role in reverse cholesterol transport and cardiovascular health.

questions.text: Which among the following organs has the least arteriovenous oxygen difference? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Kidney

 

The arteriovenous oxygen difference (A-V O2 difference) is a measure of the amount of oxygen extracted by the tissues from the blood. The greater the oxygen utilization by the tissues, the larger the A-V O2 difference.

 

  • Kidney: The kidney has the least arteriovenous oxygen difference. This is because the primary function of the kidneys is to filter large volumes of blood through the glomeruli rather than to metabolize oxygen extensively. As a result, the oxygen extracted by the renal tissues is relatively low compared to the amount of blood flow, resulting in a low A-V O2 difference.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Brain: The brain has a higher arteriovenous oxygen difference due to its significant metabolic activity and oxygen consumption to support its functions. The brain requires a constant and substantial supply of oxygen for neuronal activity, resulting in a higher A-V O2 difference compared to the kidney.

 

Option C. Skin: The skin also has a relatively low oxygen consumption compared to organs like the brain and liver, but its arteriovenous oxygen difference is still higher than that of the kidney. The skin is primarily involved in protective functions and thermoregulation, requiring less oxygen.

 

Option D. Liver: The liver has a moderate to high arteriovenous oxygen difference due to its metabolic functions, including detoxification, synthesis of proteins, and other vital activities that require substantial oxygen consumption. The liver's metabolic demands make its A-V O2 difference higher than that of the kidney.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The kidney has the least arteriovenous oxygen difference among the given organs due to its primary function of blood filtration, which requires relatively low oxygen extraction. This results in a low A-V O2 difference compared to organs like the brain and liver that have higher metabolic and oxygen consumption demands.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient with a history of chronic arthritis on treatment came with complaints of defective vision in both eyes. On examination, vision in RE = 6/12, LE = 6/18, IOP = 18 mmHg in both eyes, and the anterior segment was normal. The fundus examination and fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA) findings are shown in the figure. What is the probable diagnosis? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chloroquine toxicity

 

The patient's history of taking medication for rheumatoid arthritis and fundus with a bull's eye sign, along with the FFA image showing increased fluorescence in the macular area and round-shaped blocked fluorescence in the central fovea, suggest likely chloroquine toxicity. Here are some key points about chloroquine toxicity:

 

  • Prolonged administration of chloroquine may lead to a keratopathy, myopathy, retinopathy, and optic neuropathy.
  • Chloroquine retinopathy is a serous pigmentary degeneration of the retina that may result in vision loss.
  • A mild pigmentary disturbance in the macular area causes visual field defects, particularly a central scotoma, and a characteristic "bull's-eye" retinal lesion that can be seen on fluorescein angiography.
  • Eventually, there is a widespread retinal atrophy with pigment clumping and attenuated retinal vessels.
  • Short-term use of chloroquine can produce blurring of vision and diplopia, which is reversible upon stopping the drug.
  • Hydroxychloroquine has a lower risk of ocular toxicity than chloroquine, but it has a weaker anti-inflammatory effect.
  • The maximum dose allowed for chloroquine is 6 mg/kg in 24 hours, while for hydroxychloroquine, it is 4.5 mg/kg. Hydroxychloroquine is more commonly used today at a dose of 300-400 mg/day.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Choroiditis: This condition usually presents with patches of inflammation in the choroid, which are not observed in the provided images.

 

Option C. Steroid-induced glaucoma: This would more typically involve elevated intraocular pressure and optic nerve changes, which were not reported in the patient's examination.

 

Option D. Macular edema: While this might also involve changes in the macular region, it generally does not present with the specific "bull's eye" pattern seen in chloroquine toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 21-year-old primigravida presents to the antenatal OPD. Her school going nephew who lives in the same house has contracted varicella. A blood sample is taken for Antibodies against varicella. The report is negative. What does this signify? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Susceptible to chicken pox

 

Explanation:

 

Chickenpox in Pregnancy:

 

  • Pregnant women with uncertain or no previous history of chickenpox, who have been exposed to the infection, should have a blood test to determine their immunity to Varicella-Zoster Virus (VZV).
  • A negative antibody test indicates that the woman is not immune to VZV and is susceptible to chickenpox.
  • If a pregnant woman is not immune and has had significant exposure, she is at risk of developing chickenpox and should be administered varicella-zoster immunoglobulin (VZIG).
  • VZIG is effective up to 10 days after contact.
  • Symptomatic treatment of chickenpox in pregnancy includes:
    • Oral Acyclovir if within 24 hours of the onset of the rash and if the gestational age is greater than 20 weeks.
    • Intravenous Acyclovir should be given to all pregnant women with severe chickenpox.
  • VZIG has no therapeutic benefit once chickenpox has started.
  • Women who develop chickenpox in pregnancy should be referred to a fetal medicine specialist at 16–20 weeks or 5 weeks after infection to look for congenital varicella syndrome.
  • If the infection occurs in the last 4 weeks of pregnancy, there is a risk of varicella infection in the newborn. Planned delivery should normally be avoided for at least 7 days after the onset of the maternal rash to allow for the passive transfer of antibodies from mother to child.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Immune to chickenpox: A negative antibody test does not signify immunity; it signifies susceptibility.

 

Option C. Susceptible to zoster: Varicella-zoster virus causes both chickenpox (primary infection) and shingles (reactivation). A negative test for varicella antibodies indicates susceptibility to the primary infection (chickenpox), not to shingles.

 

Option D. Immune to zoster: Immunity to zoster would imply prior exposure to the varicella-zoster virus, which is not indicated by a negative varicella antibody test.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A negative varicella antibody test in a pregnant woman indicates that she is susceptible to chickenpox and should receive VZIG if exposed.

 

Ref: Page no 3085, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Which of the following symptoms is least likely to be observed in a patient diagnosed with Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH)? (AIIMS MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Leukemia

 

Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH) patients can progress to leukemia, but never present with it.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aplastic anemia: This is a possible complication in patients with PNH. The disease can be associated with aplastic anemia, which involves pancytopenia and bone marrow failure.

 

Option C. Thrombosis: Thrombosis, particularly in unusual sites like the hepatic veins (Budd-Chiari syndrome), is a common and severe complication of PNH. It is one of the leading causes of mortality in these patients.

 

Option D. Hemolysis: Chronic intravascular hemolysis is a hallmark of PNH, leading to symptoms such as fatigue, hemoglobinuria (often seen as dark-colored urine, especially in the morning), and anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients with PNH frequently experience hemolysis, thrombosis, and can develop aplastic anemia. While leukemia can occur as a later complication, it is not a typical presenting feature of PNH.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1213

choices.text: b, d and e only
c and e only
a and c only
Only e is correct

questions.text:
Mention the true statement/s about drug resistant malaria: (AIIMS May 2019)

 

  1. It is not present in India.
  2. Quinine with clindamycin or doxycycline is still effective treatment.
  3. Chloroquine with sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine is effective.
  4. Artemether with lumefantrine is useful.
  5. Monotherapy with artemisinin derivatives is not useful due to high risk of recrudescence.
questions.solution:
Ans. A. b, d and e only

 

  • Plasmodium falciparum is now the most common cause of malaria as well as most common cause of drug resistant malaria in India (Option a is false)
  • DOC for multiple drug resistant P falciparum is artemisinin compounds, but they are short acting. The short action is responsible for recrudescence when used as monotherapy in malaria. So they are combined with long acting drugs (known as ACT; Artemisinin based Combination Therapy) like 
  • Artemether + Lumefantrine: DOC in North-Eastern states.
  • Artesunate + Sulfadoxine/Pyrimethamine: DOC all over India except NE states.
  • Artemisinin’s are contraindicated in first trimester of pregnancy; but can be given in second and third trimester.
  • So, if drug resistant malaria occurs in 1st trimester of pregnancy, DOC is Quinine. To reduce its toxicity, we commonly add clindamycin (in pregnancy and children) or doxycycline (in other patients).
  • Chloroquine is not effective in drug resistant malaria. So artesunate (not Chloroquine) is combined with sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine (Option c)  

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is not present in India. False. Drug-resistant malaria is present in India. Plasmodium falciparum, known for drug resistance, is a common cause of malaria in India.

 

Option C. Chloroquine with sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine is effective. False. Chloroquine is not effective in drug-resistant malaria. Artemisinin-based combination therapies (ACTs) are preferred.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Drug-resistant malaria in India is effectively treated with ACTs like Artemether with lumefantrine. Monotherapy with artemisinin derivatives is avoided due to the risk of recrudescence.

 

Reference: - KDT 8TH/876-877

choices.text: Right internal jugular vein
Cervical sympathetic chain
Left vagus nerve
Right internal carotid artery

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl committed suicide by hanging, after a fight with her boyfriend. On conducting the autopsy, the ligature mark is seen at the lower 1/3rd of the neck and she is seen to have a protruded tongue. One side eye is open and both the pupils are dilated. What is the cause for the open eye? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Cervical sympathetic chain

 

In hanging, the ligature knot presses the cervical sympathetic Ganglion, this causes eye on the same side to remain open and pupil dilated.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Right internal jugular vein: Compression would cause venous congestion but is not directly related to the open eye and dilated pupil.

 

Option C. Left vagus nerve: Compression would affect parasympathetic innervation, potentially leading to bradycardia, but not the open eye and dilated pupil.

 

Option D. Right internal carotid artery: Compression could lead to ischemia, but it does not explain the unilateral open eye and pupil dilation.

 

Educational Objective

 

PM findings of hanging in the Neck

 

  • Petechiae-Tardieu spot
  • La facies sympathique
  • Salivary dribbling
  • Ligature mark
  • Tissues under ligature mark are dry, pale, and glistening
  • Thyroid cartilage
  • Hyoid bone fracture

choices.text: Endothelial injury of vessel due to HTN
Arterial internal elastic lamina defect

questions.text: Berry aneurysm occurs due to? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arterial internal elastic lamina defect

 

Berry aneurysm occurs due an arterial internal elastic lamina defect.

 

Berry (Saccular) aneurysms occur when there is collagen deficiency in the internal elastic lamina and breakdown of the tunica media. An outpouching, consisting of only tunica intima and adventitia, protrudes through the defect in the internal elastic lamina and tunica media to produce the aneurismal sac

 

As an aneurysm develops, it typically forms a neck with a dome and the arterial internal elastic lamina disappears at the base of the neck. The media thins and connective tissue replaces the smooth-muscle cells. The site of rupture is most often the dome. Here the wall thins, and the tear that allows bleeding is usually ≤0.5 mm long.

 

The most frequent cause of clinically significant subarachnoid hemorrhage is rupture of a saccular (berry) aneurysm.

 

Saccular/ Berry aneurysm is the most common type of intracranial aneurysm. About 90% of saccular aneurysms are found near major arterial branch points in the anterior circulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endothelial injury of vessel due to HTN: While hypertension (HTN) is a risk factor that can exacerbate the progression of an aneurysm, it is not the primary cause of Berry aneurysm formation. The initial defect occurs in the internal elastic lamina.

 

Option C. Endothelial layer defect: The endothelial layer is the innermost lining of blood vessels, but defects in this layer alone do not cause Berry aneurysms. The structural weakness in Berry aneurysms is primarily related to the internal elastic lamina and the underlying media.

 

Option D. Adventitia defect: The adventitia is the outermost layer of the blood vessel, but defects in the adventitia alone are not responsible for the formation of Berry aneurysms. The crucial defect is in the internal elastic lamina.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Berry aneurysms occur due to a defect in the arterial internal elastic lamina, leading to a weakened vessel wall and the potential for aneurysmal outpouching and rupture.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male construction worker presents to the emergency department with painful muscle spasms, lockjaw, and difficulty swallowing. He has a history of a deep puncture wound sustained three days ago while working on a construction site, and he did not receive any recent vaccinations. Physical examination reveals severe muscle rigidity and episodes of arching back spasms (opisthotonos). The clinical presentation strongly suggests tetanus. Which component of the fusion exocytosis complex is primarily affected in tetanus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Synaptobrevin

 

Explanation:

 

Synaptobrevin, also known as VAMP (vesicle-associated membrane protein), is a critical component of the SNARE complex, which facilitates the fusion of synaptic vesicles with the presynaptic membrane, allowing the release of neurotransmitters into the synaptic cleft. In tetanus, the tetanus neurotoxin specifically targets synaptobrevin by cleaving it, thereby disrupting vesicle fusion. This prevents the release of inhibitory neurotransmitters like GABA and glycine, which normally inhibit motor neurons. The loss of inhibitory control leads to unchecked muscle contractions and spastic paralysis, hallmark features of tetanus.

 

Other Options:

 

A. Munc18: Munc18 is a protein that assists in vesicle docking and fusion by interacting with the SNARE complex, particularly syntaxin. While it plays an essential role in exocytosis, it is not directly targeted by tetanus toxin.

 

B. Complexin: Complexin is a protein that regulates SNARE-mediated vesicle fusion by stabilizing the SNARE complex before neurotransmitter release. Although it is involved in neurotransmission, it is not cleaved or affected by tetanus toxin.

 

C. Rab3A: Rab3A is a small GTPase involved in vesicle trafficking and docking to the synaptic membrane. It helps in the precise targeting of synaptic vesicles but is not affected by tetanus toxin, which specifically cleaves synaptobrevin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In tetanus, the tetanus neurotoxin cleaves synaptobrevin (VAMP), a key component of the SNARE complex, inhibiting the release of inhibitory neurotransmitters such as GABA and glycine. This disruption in neurotransmitter release leads to muscle hyperactivity and spastic paralysis, characteristic of tetanus infection. Understanding the role of synaptobrevin in this process is critical in grasping the pathophysiology of tetanus.

questions.text: The given condition is caused by which drug? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bleomycin

 

  • The given image shows flagellate dermatitis. It is caused by bleomycin.
  • Flagellate dermatoses are infrequent types of figurate dermatoses characterized by parallel lines or curves resembling whiplash marks.
  • Bleomycin, a polypeptide chemotherapeutic agent, primarily affects the respiratory and cutaneous systems, likely due to the absence of the inactivating enzyme hydrolase in these tissues.

 

 

  • It manifests as widespread, itchy, flagellate, erythematous plaques on the trunk and extremities within hours to months after bleomycin administration.
  • Flagellate hyperpigmentation may persist even after the rash has resolved.
  • While there is no specific treatment for this condition, avoiding bleomycin can lead to clearance of the symptoms over several months to years.
  • However, re-exposure to the drug might trigger a more severe reaction.
  • Bleomycin is also associated with development of pulmonary fibrosis.
  • Peplomycin, a bleomycin derivative with reduced pulmonary toxicity, is utilized in the treatment of prostatic carcinoma and lymphomas. Nevertheless, it has been associated with flagellate erythema through mechanisms like those of bleomycin.

 

Other Options:

 

 

Bleomycin, on the other hand, can cause skin side effects like flagellate erythema, which appears as streaky red or hyperpigmented lines on the skin, resembling the appearance in the image provided. This particular side effect is a hallmark of Bleomycin toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For medical students and residents, it is crucial to identify bleomycin as the chemotherapeutic agent that can cause flagellate hyperpigmentation, a dermatological side effect not commonly associated with actinomycin, mitomycin C, or doxorubicin.
