Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I, Chapter 4 & 120, Page no 4.12 & 120.8

Goodman & Gillman’s The pharmacological basis of therapeutics 13th edition Page no 1193

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3702947/

https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/share/F7KSRDKWUJX3W2GZTEAC?target=10.1002/ski2.92

questions.text: In a preterm baby with respiratory distress syndrome, which of the following lipid would be deficient?( NEET PG 2020 )
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dipalmitoyl phosphatidyl choline

 

This is the correct answer. DPPC is a major component of pulmonary surfactant, and its deficiency in preterm infants is a key factor in the development of RDS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sphingomyelin: Sphingomyelin is not the deficient lipid in RDS. While it is a component of pulmonary surfactant, the primary deficiency in RDS is of DPPC.

 

L:S (Lecithin: Sphingomyelin) ratio > 2 is an indicator of fetal lung maturity at 32 weeks of gestation.

 

Option B. Cardiolipin: Cardiolipin is not the deficient lipid in RDS. It is found in the inner mitochondrial membrane and is not directly related to pulmonary surfactant.

 

Disease related to Cardiolipins

 

  1. Barth Syndrome: Defect in cardiolipin remodelling
  2. Anti-Phospholipid Syndrome: Occurs due to Anticardiolipin antibodies formed in body. C/f are A thrombotic condition and Disease females has history of recurrent infection

 

Option D. None of the above: This option is incorrect because, as explained above, DPPC is deficient in preterm babies with RDS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

RDS occurs when there is not enough surfactant in the lungs. Surfactant is a liquid made by the lungs that keeps the airways (alveoli) open. Pulmonary surfactant is a surface-active lipoprotein complex (phospholipoprotein) formed by type II alveolar cells. The proteins and lipids that make up the surfactant have both hydrophilic and hydrophobic regions. By adsorbing to the air-water interface of alveoli, with hydrophilic head groups in the water and the hydrophobic tails facing towards the air, the main lipid component of surfactant is dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine (DPPC).

 

Ref- Harper 31st ed pg – 234

questions.text: During total thyroidectomy for papillary thyroid cancer, which of the following steps will not lead to hoarseness of voice?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dissection of strap muscles

 

Hoarseness of voice after thyroidectomy is generally due to injury to the recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN), which controls the vocal cords. The RLN is located near the thyroid gland, and careful surgical technique is necessary to avoid damaging it. The strap muscles, which are located anterior to the thyroid gland, are far from the path of the RLN, so dissecting these muscles will not result in hoarseness of voice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option  A. Dissection of Beahr’s triangle: The recurrent laryngeal nerve forms the anterior boundary of Beahr’s triangle, making it susceptible to injury during dissection, which can lead to hoarseness.

 

Option B. Dissection of Zuckerkandl tubercle: The Zuckerkandl tubercle is closely associated with the recurrent laryngeal nerve, so dissection in this area can risk nerve injury and subsequent hoarseness.

 

Option D. Ligation of Superior thyroid artery: This procedure is generally more likely to affect the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve rather than the recurrent laryngeal nerve, but in cases of anatomical variation, there is a small risk that the RLN could be affected, potentially leading to hoarseness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dissection of the strap muscles during thyroidectomy does not involve the recurrent laryngeal nerve, and therefore, will not cause hoarseness of voice.

questions.text: In gunshot injury to skull with entry wound at right temporal region surrounded by abrasion collar & tattooing and an exit wound at left temporal region along with metal fragments of bullet inside the bullet track, what can be used to determine the range of firing? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hair  

 

The singeing of hair, along with blackening and tattooing, can be used to determine the range of firing in gunshot injuries.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B) Bullet pieces: They can be present irrespective of the distance

 

Option C) Blood: Not helpful to determine distance

 

Option D) Clothes: Not helpful as the bullet wound is on head. In other body parts clothes would have been helpful

 

Educational Objective:

 

Entry Wound features:

 

  • Contact Shot: Singeing, blackening and tattooing present just on the margin; not around the wound. Very minimally visible.
  • Close Shot: Singeing, blackening and tattooing present in large amount around the wound (esp. blackening is prominent)
  • Intermediate Range: Only Tattooing present around the wound
  • Distant range: None of these present around the wound.

questions.text: Identify the type of skin lesion? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Annular

 

The given image shows annular lesions, which are ring shaped with central clearing i.e., only the edges are active & appear raised, or in different colour. It is present in granuloma annulare and tinea corporis.

 

 

 

 

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Nummular: Nummular lesions are coin-shaped and may be mistaken for annular lesions. However, nummular lesions are usually more solid in appearance without the central clearing seen in annular lesions.

 

Option C. Discoid: Discoid lesions are disc-like and typically solid without a central clearing. They can be seen in conditions like discoid lupus erythematosus. The lesion in the image is not entirely solid as it has central clearing, which is not characteristic of discoid lesions.

 

Option D. Target: Target lesions have a bulls-eye appearance with multiple rings and a dusky center as shown in the image below.

 

 

They are typically associated with conditions such as erythema multiforme. The lesion in the image does not have the concentric rings of color that define a target lesion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Annular lesions is identified by their characteristic ring-like appearance with central clearing, differentiating them from nummular, discoid, and target lesions.

 

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition volume I Chapter 4. Page no 4.11- 4.13

questions.text: A resident physician sustained a needlestick injury while collecting a blood sample from a patient with HIV. It has been decided to provide the physician with post-exposure prophylaxis. What would be the most suitable course of action among the options below? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Lamivudine+ Tenofovir+ Dolutegravir for 4 weeks 

 

Post Exposure Prophylaxis HIV

 

Preferably within 24 hours. Maximum within 72 hours.

 

Dose - Tenofovir (300 mg) + Lamivudine (300 mg) + Dolutegravir (50 mg) as 1 tablet/drug OD

 

Duration of PEP is 28 days, irrespective of Regimen type

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the curves shown in the image best represents the Gibbs free energy change of an enzyme-catalyzed reaction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Curve A

 

Explanation:

 

Curve A represents the Gibbs free energy change of an enzyme-catalyzed reaction. Enzymes lower the activation energy required for a reaction by stabilizing the transition state, which is the highest energy point on the reaction pathway. This reduction in activation energy is visually depicted as a lower peak compared to an uncatalyzed reaction. The enzyme provides a specific environment that facilitates the formation of the enzyme-substrate complex, leading to a more efficient path to the product without altering the overall Gibbs free energy change of the reaction.

 

Other Options:

 

B. Curve B: This curve represents a typical reaction without enzyme catalysis, where the activation energy required to reach the transition state is much higher compared to an enzyme-catalyzed reaction.

 

C. Curve C: This curve does not depict any significant activation energy barrier, indicating it is not representative of a typical reaction pathway with or without an enzyme.

 

D. Curve D: This curve shows a pathway with reduced energy states but does not adequately represent the role of an enzyme in lowering the activation energy compared to Curve A.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In enzyme-catalyzed reactions, enzymes reduce the activation energy required to reach the transition state, thereby speeding up the reaction without altering the Gibbs free energy of the substrates or products. Understanding the effect of enzymes on reaction energetics is crucial for comprehending how enzymes function as biological catalysts.

choices.text: Chordee correction, meatal advancement, urethral mobilization, glanuloplasty
Meatal advancement, chordee correction, glanuloplasty, urethral mobilization

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct sequence for correction of hypospadias surgery? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chordee correction, urethral mobilization, glanuloplasty

 

  • Proximal hypospadias with chordee needs surgical correction and may involve a two-stage repair. The first stage corrects the penile curvature and the second stage repairs the urethra. Circumcision should be avoided as preputial skin may be required for future repairs or revisions. Surgery for hypospadias is best performed by experts in hypospadias surgery and is typically undertaken before the age of 18 months
  • Chordee correction involves straightening the penis, which may have a downward curvature.
  • Urethral mobilization involves the dissection of the urethra from the corpora cavernosa and mobilizing it to a normal anatomical position.
  • Glanuloplasty involves the reconstruction of the glans penis to provide a cosmetically pleasing appearance and improve function.
  • Meatal advancement involves the creation of a normal urethral meatus at the tip of the penis.

questions.text: Which of the following can be prescribed in case of an open angle glaucoma with bronchial asthma? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Latanoprost

 

Latanoprost is a Prostaglandin, PGF2α analog, that acts in glaucoma by increasing the uveoscleral outflow of aqueous humor and is used as a first line drug in patients with open angle glaucoma. It can be safely used in bronchial asthma, as it does not cause bronchospasm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Timolol: Timolol is a beta-blocker that can cause bronchospasm as a systemic side effect. Therefore, it is not recommended for patients with bronchial asthma.

 

Option B. Gemeprost: Gemeprost is a prostaglandin E1 (PGE1) analog used for the termination of pregnancy. It is not relevant for the treatment of glaucoma.

 

Option D. Mannitol infusion: Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic used in the treatment of acute angle-closure glaucoma, not open-angle glaucoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Latanoprost, a prostaglandin F2α analog, is safe and effective for the treatment of open-angle glaucoma in patients with bronchial asthma, as it does not cause bronchospasm.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked with a yellow question mark ? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inner nuclear layer

 

The marked structure in the slide is the inner nuclear layer of the retina

 

  • Present between the outer plexiform layer and the inner plexiform layer.
  • Contains the cell bodies of bipolar cells, horizontal cells, and amacrine cells.
  • Dark stain.

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
You are posted as an intern in casualty. An elderly 60-year-old man is brought to you with complaints of chest pain. He has tested positive for COVID. Which of the following features will prompt you to get this patient admitted to dedicated COVID health centre? (INICET NOV 2020)

 

A. Respiratory rate of 25/min

B. SpO2 93%

C. Multiple comorbidities

D. Age
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A, B, C & D only

 

A & B Respiratory rate of 25/min and SpO2 93% : Both of these values are indicative of potential respiratory compromise, which is concerning in a COVID-19 patient. These values suggest the need for closer monitoring and possible oxygen supplementation.

 

C. Multiple comorbidities: Patients with multiple comorbidities are at a higher risk of severe disease and complications from COVID-19, warranting admission for close monitoring and treatment.

 

D. Age: Age is a known risk factor for severity and complications in COVID-19. Older patients, like the 60-year-old man in the scenario, generally have poorer outcomes and may benefit from hospital care.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When evaluating a COVID-19 patient for hospital admission, consider clinical signs of respiratory distress, overall oxygen saturation, presence of comorbidities, and age due to their significant impacts on disease severity and outcome.

choices.text: Removing clothes to inspect for wounds
Taking CT scan of the patient

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the primary survey? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Taking CT scan of the patient

 

Taking CT scan of the patient: Incorrect. This is not part of the primary survey. After the primary survey, if the patient is stabilized, a secondary survey is conducted which is a more thorough examination and may involve advanced imaging like CT scans to further delineate injuries.

 

Taking a CT scan of the patient is a part of secondary survey.

 

Primary survey consists of five components, remembered by the mnemonic "ABCDE":

 

  1. Airway maintenance with cervical spine protection: The first step is to ensure the patient has a patent (open) airway, and to protect the cervical spine in case of potential injury.
  2. Breathing and ventilation: This step includes assessing the patient's breathing and ventilation. This can involve checking for symmetric chest rise, listening for breath sounds, and looking for any signs of respiratory distress or chest injury.
  3. Circulation with haemorrhage control: This involves assessing the patient's circulation and looking for signs of active bleeding. Measures such as fluid resuscitation may be initiated during this step if the patient is in shock.
  4. Disability: This involves a quick evaluation of the patient's neurological status, often using the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS).
  5. Exposure/Environmental control: The patient should be fully undressed to allow a complete examination. However, care should be taken to prevent hypothermia, which can worsen outcomes in trauma patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Measuring blood pressure: This is a part of assessing Circulation.

 

Option B. Removing clothes to inspect for wounds: This is a part of Exposure/Environmental control. It's crucial to remove clothing so that injuries aren't missed. However, while ensuring exposure, care should also be taken to maintain the patient's body temperature and prevent hypothermia.

 

Option D. Checking airway patency: This is part of Airway maintenance with cervical spine protection. Ensuring a clear airway is a top priority. Airway obstruction takes least time to death.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary survey in trauma care includes Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability, and Exposure/Environmental control. Advanced imaging studies like CT scans are part of the secondary survey, conducted after initial stabilization.

questions.text:
A 6-month-old infant is brought to the pediatrician due to developmental delays and feeding difficulties. The parents report that the child has had poor muscle tone since birth and has been slow to achieve milestones like sitting up and holding objects. On physical examination, the infant has distinct facial features, including a broad nasal bridge and micrognathia. The child also has a history of recurrent ear infections and a heart murmur detected during a recent check-up. Genetic testing was ordered, and the karyotype is shown below.

 

 

Based on the marked chromosome abnormality, what type of chromosome structure is most likely present?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Acrocentric

 

Explanation:

 

The marked chromosome is chromosome 13, which is classified as an acrocentric chromosome. Acrocentric chromosomes have their centromere positioned close to one end, creating a very short "p" arm and a long "q" arm. This unique structure is a hallmark of acrocentric chromosomes, which include chromosomes 13, 14, 15, 21, and 22 in humans. These chromosomes often participate in Robertsonian translocations, which can contribute to various genetic syndromes associated with developmental and physical abnormalities.

 

Other Options:

 

A. Submetacentric: Submetacentric chromosomes have the centromere slightly off-center, resulting in arms of unequal length. This does not describe chromosome 13, which has a distinctly short p arm and a long q arm characteristic of acrocentric chromosomes.

 

C. Metacentric: Metacentric chromosomes have a centrally located centromere, leading to arms of approximately equal length. This structure is not typical of chromosome 13.

 

D. Telocentric: Telocentric chromosomes have their centromere at the terminal end, with only one arm. Telocentric chromosomes are not normally found in humans, and this description does not fit chromosome 13.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acrocentric chromosomes, such as chromosome 13, have a centromere near one end, creating a short p arm and a long q arm. This structure is significant in genetic disorders and abnormalities due to the frequent involvement of acrocentric chromosomes in translocations and genetic imbalances. Recognizing the distinct structure of acrocentric chromosomes is crucial in diagnosing and understanding various congenital conditions

 

Chromosomes are classified based on the position of the centromere as follows:

choices.text: Repeated radical surgery every 24 hours may be required to adequately manage this condition
This is a case of Meleney's gangrene
The condition is caused by beta Hemolytic streptococcus and may sometimes be polymicrobial
Hyperbaric oxygen has no role in the treatment of this condition

questions.text: Which of the following statement is false about the given condition?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hyperbaric oxygen has no role in the treatment of this condition

 

  • The image depicts necrotizing fasciitis of the abdominal wall, also known as Meleney's gangrene.
  • This condition is a severe soft tissue infection characterized by rapidly spreading inflammation and necrosis.
  • Hyperbaric oxygen therapy has been shown to have some benefit in managing this condition.

 

Meleney's Gangrene (Necrotizing Fasciitis)

 

  • Clinical Features: Signs of local inflammation, skin gangrene, and features of septicemia such as hypotension and fever.
  • Investigation: Culture swab tests usually reveal aerobes (such as beta-hemolytic Streptococci) and anaerobes, making the condition often polymicrobial.
  • Treatment:
    • Surgical: Radical wide debridement is necessary and may need to be repeated every 24-48 hours to manage the infection effectively.
    • Medical: Intravenous antibiotics are critical to treating the infection.
    • Adjunctive Therapy: Hyperbaric oxygen therapy has some benefits and is used as an adjunct in the management of necrotizing fasciitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Repeated radical surgery every 24 hours may be required to adequately manage this condition: True: Radical wide debridement is often needed repeatedly (every 24-48 hours) to control the spread of the infection and remove necrotic tissue.

 

Option B. This is a case of Meleney's gangrene: True: The condition shown in the image is Meleney's gangrene, a specific form of necrotizing fasciitis.

 

Option C. The condition is caused by beta Hemolytic streptococcus and may sometimes be polymicrobial: True: The infection can be caused by beta-hemolytic Streptococci and is often polymicrobial, involving both aerobic and anaerobic bacteria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Meleney's gangrene, or necrotizing fasciitis, requires aggressive surgical debridement, intravenous antibiotics, and may benefit from adjunctive hyperbaric oxygen therapy.
  • The condition is often polymicrobial, involving both aerobic and anaerobic bacteria.

questions.text: A patient displaying lytic lesions on the skull is being considered for a diagnosis of Langerhans cell histiocytosis. What represents a distinctive discovery on electron microscopy among the following options? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Birbeck granules

 

The presence of Birbeck granules in the cytoplasm is a characteristic finding of Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) on electron microscopy.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Histiocytes: While Langerhans cells are a type of histiocyte, the presence of histiocytes alone is not specific to LCH. The defining feature is the presence of Birbeck granules.

 

Option C. Eosinophils: Eosinophils are often present in LCH lesions, especially in eosinophilic granuloma, but they are not a distinctive finding on electron microscopy.

 

Option D. Giant cells: Giant cells may be present in a variety of inflammatory or granulomatous conditions, but they are not specific to LCH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of Birbeck granules on electron microscopy is a distinctive and pathognomonic finding in Langerhans cell histiocytosis.

questions.text: A patient has been diagnosed with Luminal A type of breast carcinoma. Which of the following best describes the marker profile in her? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ER+, PR+, HER2- Low Ki67

 

  • Luminal A breast carcinoma is characterized by hormone receptor positivity and low proliferation rates. The expression profile typically includes estrogen receptor positive (ER+), progesterone receptor positive (PR+), and human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 negative (HER2-). Additionally, this subtype is marked by a low Ki67 index, indicating a lower proliferation rate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ER+, PR+, HER2- High Ki67: This combination, while similar in hormone receptor status, features a high Ki67 index, suggestive of a more aggressive subtype like Luminal B cancer.

 

Option C. ER+, PR+, HER2+ High Ki67: This profile describes a HER2-positive and high-proliferation subtype (often seen in more aggressive breast cancers).

 

Option D. ER-, PR-, HER2- High Ki67: Known as triple-negative breast cancer, this profile is markedly different from Luminal A as it lacks expression of ER, PR, and HER2, and is associated with higher grade tumors.

 

Educational objective:

 

Luminal A breast carcinoma is characterized by positive hormone receptors (ER and PR), absence of HER2 expression, and low Ki67 levels, indicative of a slower-growing, less aggressive tumor that typically has a better prognosis compared to other subtypes.

questions.text: Which lymphoma is strongly associated with overexpression of BCL2? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Follicular lymphoma

 

Follicular lymphoma is associated with overexpression of BCL2.

 

Normal cells include the BCL2 gene, however this gene's mutant version with the recognizable translocation t (14;18) (q32; q21) was originally identified in B-cell lymphoma, hence the term BCL.

 

Numerous other human malignancies, including those of the breast, thyroid, and prostate, also exhibit it.

 

Due to a mutation in the BCL2 gene, more living cells are undergoing mitosis, which contributes to the formation of tumors by removing the apoptosis-inhibitory control on cancer cells.

 

The most prevalent chromosomal translocation in human lymphomas, the t(14;18)  (q32;q21) is found in up to 30% of diffuse large B-cell lymphomas and over 85% of follicular lymphomas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Burkitt lymphoma: Characterized by the c-MYC gene translocation, not BCL2 overexpression.

 

Option C. Diffuse large-cell lymphoma: While BCL2 can be overexpressed due to the same translocation, it is more typically associated with follicular lymphoma.

 

Option D. Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL): CLL can also exhibit overexpression of BCL2, but this is generally due to other genetic mechanisms rather than the t(14;18) translocation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Follicular lymphoma is primarily associated with the overexpression of BCL2 due to the t(14;18) chromosomal translocation. This genetic alteration is a critical factor in the pathogenesis of follicular lymphoma, enabling lymphoma cells to evade apoptosis and sustain tumor growth. Understanding the role of BCL2 in various lymphomas helps in differentiating among them and tailoring appropriate therapeutic strategies.

questions.text: HPV Nonavalent vaccine is active against which of the following serotypes? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, 58

 

Explanation:

 

HPV Vaccines available are:

 

  1. Cervarix (Bivalent): 16, 18
  2. Gardasil (Quadrivalent): 6, 11, 16, 18
  3. Nonavalent: (Gardasil 9 or HPV9): 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, 58.
  4. Cervavac (India’s indigenous HPV vaccine): Quadrivalent: 6, 11, 16, 18

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Gardasil 9 is a nonavalent HPV vaccine effective against 9 serotypes of the virus
  • These include: 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, 58.

 

Ref: https://www.merckvaccines.com/gardasil9/
